segments.text: in a normal tone.
Where are you going to place that?
Let's put it right here.
That way I can watch it.
Well, some say you have a low voice and that you're God's gift to the radio kingdom, but I don't know if it's going to sound that way when we play this tape back.
So what do you think about that?
Well, all we care about is that we can be heard, right?
So if you can type this away, we won't have any screw-ups.
We set?
Let's see, we're recording on 20 March 1986, sitting in the living room up on Summit Avenue, and Chuck is about to ask me some penetrating questions.
That's right.
So why don't you first tell us a little bit about yourself?
That was Chuck.
Hi, squeaky voice.
I'm God's gift to women.
That's for certain, boys.
What would you like to know?
The background?
A quick biographical background, and then your time in Nam, what you spent and what you did.
OK. Well, I was born on January 8, 1946, on a log cabin in southern Minnesota.
And I was drafted on October 3, 1968.
I went on down to basic training at Fort Campbell, Kentucky.
And about the first week in December, we flew over.
We graduated.
Our basic training company graduated.
And we flew on over to Fort Lewis, Washington.
and did AIT, which is advanced infantry training, in the snow at Fort Lewis in preparation of going to the jungles of Vietnam.
That concluded the end of February.
I then had a short leave and went to the non-commissioned officer's candidate school at the infantry school at Fort Benning, Georgia.
Graduated from there at the end of June
Then drove back to Fort Lewis, Washington where I was platoon sergeant for a platoon of AIT infantry cadets.
And then I had a three week leave and arrived in Nam at the end of sometime in September, early September.
And I was assigned to the 25th Infantry Division.
Spent a couple of days at Koo Chee in processing.
Infantry Division.
And we were called the Wolfhounds.
And our area of operation was adjacent to the Cambodian border, northwest of Saigon.
So, going into NAMM, why, what was your purpose?
Why did you think you were going?
What was your job to be accomplished?
My feeling was that my father was a World War I Marine and a World War II Army officer, and an extremely patriotic and fair sort of person.
And the prevailing political belief in our community, in our farming community, was that

The military leaders and the political leaders were sending us over there because of the Red Menace and that it was necessary to combat communism, monolithic communism, over there before it got to our shores.
And now when did you leave Vietnam?
Left Vietnam on July 10th, 1970.
And how were you greeted at home upon your arrival?
Not very warmly.
I was called a baby killer shortly after getting into California.
And people didn't seem to care.
Other vets would talk to you.
And it was a big camaraderie.
And it was like we were an exclusive union of people who the rest of society didn't quite know what to think of us.
Well, what was your feeling to the war that was going on then while you were in the States then?
Yeah, as I came back.
Yeah, from when you first arrived, how did your attitude change, if indeed it had?
Within about three weeks of getting into country, two to three weeks, my attitude began to change.
I thought that we were saving these people, we were, you know, over there, liberators, helping them, that they were welcoming us with open arms.
When I got out into the countryside and we got into areas that supposedly no American troops had ever been in before,

the people there were afraid of us, which might be quite natural, because for years they had the French terrorizing them, and then they had the VC terrorizing them and taking their rice, and now they had us, and if they were too friendly toward us, the VC would note that and come back that night and do something, harm them.

So my attitude changed from one of, well, this is a good idea, and I'm sure everything's progressing well, and we've got the best minds and the best and the brightest thinking about this and doing it, to one of the South Vietnamese troops were not pulling an equal share.
The South Vietnamese civilians were afraid of us.
They didn't seem to know how.
They may not have been so afraid of us, but they didn't know how to handle us.
And they were caught between the VC and us.
But the feeling that they gave us was not one of overwhelming welcome, in my opinion.
So then these feelings, are they the reasons, or you ended up joining the Veterans Against the War?
What made you do that?
Well, going back to that about three weeks to a month,
After being in country, as my attitude began to change after being there two weeks, two more weeks down the road, I'm only in country a month, we're getting casualties.
We're in a heavy booby-trapped area.
They snipe at us.
We rarely at this point engage a large group of enemy.
It's snipers and booby traps.
And almost daily, every other day, somebody was injured by a booby trap.
And just the responses that we had, you know, we were limited in our responses.
They were across the border.
We couldn't do anything about it.
It was, you know, we operated on body counts and the... Well, specifically though, I mean, you get home and your attitudes change, but...
What was it that, why did you, your reasons for joining the VBAW?
Well, it was a good night last night.
A month after being there, I came to realize that the people above me in the chain of command didn't really want to hear what I thought about what was going on.
They didn't want to hear what my men thought.
I started out as a squad leader.
A month later, I was a platoon sergeant.
They didn't want to hear.
The war had been diagnosed.

It had been decided by computers and statistical data, primarily by McNamara, Secretary of Defense McNamara, that the war was being won and it was progressing in a certain way and it should be done this way.
And the military leaders above us apparently did not want to have data and figures presented to them and ideas which disproved that or were contrary to that.
And so instead of coming out with a grassroots level, having an open-door policy, the general never came out and said, hey, what do you guys think about how we ought to do things?
It was always, well, this is the way we're doing it, and there's a grand strategy, and we really don't care that you think otherwise.
So then you thought the veterans against the war was a means of expressing what wasn't being expressed at NAM.
Absolutely.
And also, the VFW and American Legion had indicated that they very clearly supported the American effort, a political position they had to take.
But they also indicated that the veterans of Vietnam supported the effort.
And that was not true in my area, and it was not true with a lot of veterans.
And we were on the cutting edge of, we were the first veterans to say, we don't believe in the war, the war isn't being run right.
What the press tells us, what the military tells the press to tell the people here, there's a lot of factual inaccuracy, and we want to set the record straight.
And we think we're over there dying and we're not going to win the war.
I arrived in country in September of 1969.
My feeling by October, sometime in October, was that we were not going to win the war because the South Vietnamese were not going to support us strongly enough once we were removed.
It just seemed apparent at that point to me and to the people in my unit that that was going to happen.
I don't think anyone really thought that the South Vietnamese were going to keep the North Vietnamese out once we left.
So when was it then that you joined the Veterans Against the War?
About six months after I got back and tried to get into some normalcy again.
I was at school and I noticed the signs around campus saying,
Vietnam Veterans Against the War Meeting Room, such and such.
And I didn't know whether I wanted to get into it with these people or not, and I didn't know what they stood for.

And so I kind of walked by the room a number of times and paused and listened to the conversations going on and smoked a cigarette outside the door, trying to decide whether I wanted to talk to these people or whether they represented something other than I did.
And so I joined them, ended up joining them about nine months after I got back.
I probably joined them in the winter of January, February of 1971.
Now this was on, what campus was this?
The beautiful campus of Mankato State College, where tuition is low and girls are easy.
So when you joined, did you find that they reflected the same things that you were thinking then?
Everyone had their own slightly unique perspective, but there was a common thread which bound the veterans there in that group that
And the thread was that the government, our government, was lying to the military.
The military was lying to the government, and they were both lying to the people here about what was going on.
Because we were always winning the war.
There were major new breakthroughs, new developments.
We were continually turning the corner
on the war over there.
But yet we were over there.
We saw the headlines in the American papers that our relatives would send to us while we were in Vietnam, which would say that we were turning the corner.
But yet we felt very clearly that was not the case, that this was all media hyperbole.
That's hyperbole.
What then was the size of the organization that you joined, would you say?
When I joined, there were probably about 25 members on a roll that would usually get together once a week.
We would have between 20 and 25 people showing up once a week.
And then we began to socialize outside of those meetings, run into each other in the union, have more discussions.
Did you eventually work your way up into some sort of...
official position, or were you just one of the members?
Yeah, I did.
After, from that 25-member start, we decided that it wasn't enough to just gather in a room and talk about this.
We contacted a printing company, and we had some mailers developed.
We were able to get the school to release the name of all the veterans on campus.
So we mailed to every veteran on campus.

and asked them if they were interested in joining, and asked them what their political views were, and encouraged them to come on down to one of our meetings, regardless of their political views, because we wanted this to be a group of veterans, rather than a select group who had a specific idea.
We wanted it to be as encompassing as we possibly could.
And eventually I became regional coordinator for Minnesota, Iowa, and the North Dakotas and Montana, five-state region.
Now, that seems like a fairly quick, when you say you eventually became the coordinator now, was that a fairly short period of time or?
I mean, it was probably over a four-month period, three to four-month period.
How do you account for rising so high, let's say, so quickly?
Because I was very much less burnt out at that point than other vets were.
I was probably, I had a better media image.
I was more articulate and less, definitely less radical.
And in meetings, I strongly believe in the democratic process and the marketplace of ideas.
And I want to hear what everybody thinks.
And that's kind of why.
People just said, well, he doesn't have the long hair.
He represents a good image.
He states our position well.
Let's make him deal with the public.
Because we don't want a long hair who looks like a radical hippie trying to get these points across because we'll only...
hurt the points we're trying to make.
You mentioned radical.
Did you have some radicals within?
And if so, what do you mean by radical?
Well, yeah, we had people whose ideas about any number of things were more radical than mine.
You know, radical being noticeably different than what most people perceived the mainstream idea to be at that time.
We had some who claimed that they didn't care what happened to the American POWs in Vietnam.

You know, a stance that we didn't agree with, but there was one person in particular who always used to argue that the American pilots in the Air Force who flew the bombing missions who got shot down and were in captivity deserved it because they were indiscriminately bombing.
And that's not a position the rest of us identified with or agreed to.
Well, as regional coordinator then, what were your tactics in trying to have the truth be known?
We contacted, we started out in the Mankato area and the Minneapolis-St. Paul area, in the Mankato area.

We contacted the Kiwanis Club, the Lions Clubs, the various schools in the area, the political parties, and we had a group, a team of four of us, who would go out and address, say, the Hilltop Kiwanis Noon Luncheon Meetings and present our views and try to engage in a discussion with the folks there.
And we wanted to tell them,
We're veterans.
We're patriotic veterans.
The government's saying that we're winning the war.
We are not winning the war.
At some point, we're going to pull out.
We think it's foolish to continue to commit troops on the level that we're doing it now.
Either we go in and win the war, or we ought to get out.
Because once we leave, we believed that there was going to be a bloodbath and that we were eventually going to lose.
So we did that in the Mankato area.
In the St. Paul, Minneapolis area, we conducted the same things on the university campus.
On all of the campuses in the area, we would come on and set up booths, talk to people, try and conduct rallies, send speakers.
And we would occasionally get together.
We'd call a press conference to announce this or that in relation to our activities.
Did any of these rallies meet with any resistance?
Or were they always, and by resistance I'm implying today, rallies get out of hand like they did in some points in the nation?
No, we were extremely careful.
We knew that this was happening and was creating bad press in other areas.
We didn't want rallies to get out of hand.
We didn't want a bunch of emotional people running around screaming slogans.
People to sit down and think about what we were saying and be rational and logical and view it from that perspective.
And we were extremely careful to keep things from getting out of hand.
There are always a couple of people who believe, proclaim to believe so strongly in this or that or, you know, that the government was wrong in being there that they
would say and do things which we didn't condone.
And when that happened, we'd ask them for the good of everybody to tone it down.
And only on a few occasions did they not tone it down.
By the time you joined, say in 71, Nixon had already implemented his Vietnamization.
And that in itself tended to withdraw a lot from the anti-war movement.
affect your cause at all?
Well, in our perspective, it did not tend to draw a lot to take away from the anti-war movement, the volatilism or the emotionalism, because we didn't believe that it was actually occurring.
We just believed the same thing we believed when we started, that once our troops withdrew, the country was going to go North Vietnamese.
that for whatever reasons the South Vietnamese who identified with us were not going to prevent that from happening.
They had us there for a number of years.
We never figured out how to do it.
We knew that the country was going to fall.
We thought it was silly to say that Vietnamization is occurring, that the Vietnamese are taking over the war.
They weren't taking over the war.
All they were doing is the Americans were being withdrawn, and they weren't taking over the war.
They never did.
They lost conclusively in a very short period of time,
And I don't think anyone, it just seems so impossible that anyone seriously thought that they were going to be able to defend the country.
the Arvin invasion of Laos would testify to that fact since they ended up pulling out on March 25th.
Was there any response to that from your vets against the war?
I mean, two days later, there was about 50,000 people nationwide that were protesting of some sort.
Anything up here happen in Minnesota after that in particular?

You know, our response was we'd get up in the morning and have coffee and read the Wall Street Journal or pick out the headlines and listen to the radio, find out what had occurred when something had happened.
We'd go about and we'd try and contact and set up more speaking engagements and that kind of thing.
Maybe hold a press conference up here in the Twin Cities involving some of the other local people.
And we became more involved with Citizens for Peace and some of the other peace organizations.
And we began to coordinate the veterans with the non-veteran peace organizations.
I don't specifically recall that we did anything else at that time.

Okay, because some groups, they tend to, as incidents like that happen with this, start with the invasion of Cambodia, and then now here we've got Laos, and then some of the Christmas bombings you see reciprocal or parallel anti-war demonstrations going on.
That's why I was asking that.
So by...
February, January 31st through February 2nd of 72, you had the Winter Soldier Hearings in Detroit.
Did the Minnesota charter or chapter play any part in that or any thoughts on that?
Well, we helped coordinate setting them up and lended our support to the national organization and thought it was an awfully good idea because
One of the major issues in this area at that time, as it was in the Detroit and across the nation, was that there had been a number of atrocities committed by American troops.
And the government was attempting to deny that and say that wasn't the case.
These atrocities were committed for a number of reasons.
The pressure that was put on the troops in an area, the faulty military strategy.
where Americans were continually sniped down and harassed and eventually reacted less than competently.
Well, overall, that seemed to not have much effect, though.
And maybe that's what precipitated the March on Washington and the April demonstrations.
And preceding that demonstration, the Vets Against the War had a week-long rally.
And that was typified by John Kerry's speech in Congress and then ended with the throwing the medals back over to the Capitol.
The Winter Soldier hearings in Detroit probably had a net detrimental effect to the anti-war movement because we ended up with people.
Here's the first time that a group of vets gets together and says, yes, I saw, witnessed, and was part of atrocities.
and broke down were very emotional and graphic in describing what units, during what time span, exactly what they did.
They had long hair.
They weren't the PR people.
They looked like they were emotional basket cases in a number of cases.
So here you have the first people that say Americans are committing atrocities.
They're basically saying we committed them.
They're saying we ought to get out of the war.
And they have a disheveled appearance.
So people seem to identify and say, well, those crazies did crazy things when they were in NAMM, and now they're part of Vietnam Veterans Against the War.
That must be a crazies organization.
I think it really hurt us.
Then we rebound to John Kerry, who was by far and away our most effective spokesman.
That was the high point of our organization after his congressional testimony.
Now, did you have any meetings with John Kerry?
Shortly after that, in November of that year, we held a national conference of Vietnam veterans against the war, state coordinators and regional coordinators, and the National Steering Committee.
We got together in Kansas City, and that was the second time that I met John Kerry personally.
He'd attended a rally that we had held at Mankato with a number of potential presidential candidates and local state political figures.
And he and I attended the Kansas convention.
And we were by far, in my opinion, we were the only two who were not wacko radical at that point.
In fact, Minnesota, our region,
we ended up withdrawing from the national VVAW movement because they were at a place we couldn't identify.
One of the proposals was that we make tape-recorded conversations and say, you know, hello, I'm, you know, former Sergeant so-and-so from such-and-such a unit.
You know, you Americans in Vietnam, you know, we're not winning the war.
There's no sense that you lose your life.
Why don't you do whatever you can
to cause disruption in the military, and potentially you'll get home earlier.
One of the suggestions was that a number of people do that, and we pass these tapes out to GIs.
And in my consideration, that would have been a treasonous act, and I thought it was just a lot of baloney.
And at that point,
people were talking about all kinds of bourgeoisie and all the radical political terms and were extremely emotional, but not very logical and rational.
And they'd given up the idea of conducting,
press with the people.
They weren't going to logically get through to new people so that new people who hadn't really thought about this would start to influence their congressmen.
So the democratic process would come into play.
So Kerry was against that kind of talk also?
Yeah.
He and I were the only two coordinators that I recall at this meeting who were.
And you ended up withdrawing then?
We ended up withdrawing because, yeah, we were...
Our group, I and another fellow from Minnesota, we were kind of shunned because we weren't radical enough for him.
What happened with Kerry then?

Shortly, there was a movement afoot at that time to diminish his role in VVAW because other people had banded together and either wanted the personal limelight or didn't think that his political position was radical enough.
And his prominence and his role disappeared at that point.
Also during those April demonstrations, do you think the thousand or so vets that threw back their medals, was that a radical act?
What do you think about that?
No, I don't.
I think that was a more widespread, more patriotic act.
They threw back the medals because they didn't believe
that the war was being conducted in a proper way or should have existed.
And the larger number of them tended to support the more grass-root feeling among the vets.
Well, it seemed then, after that week, that compared to the Winter Soldier hearings, that this had some positive effect.
After all, it climaxed with 500,000 people marching in Washington.
That must have been a good feeling.
It was.
It was.
And in my mind, there's no doubt but that Vietnam Veterans Against the War mobilized and made more people aware of the follies of Vietnam than any other movement.
And it probably had a greater political impact than any other organization during that 10-year time span.
You mentioned the more radical aspects.
With the continuing presence of US troops in Nam, actions got more radical.
For example, you have 1,500 students storming the ROTC building in Michigan, and such similar actions overall.
Did you have growing radicalism, say, here in the U of M?
Or how do you guys deal with that?
I mean, for instance, just to...
December 26 and 30, you've got the bombing, intensive bombing of North Vietnam, and the Vietnam vets against the war.
Some seize national monuments to make a quick protest, lock themselves up in Betsy Ross's house, or locking, staying inside the Statue of Liberty and unfolding a US flag upside down.
Did you all do anything?
like that?
We didn't do anything like that.
We tried to increase our getting more press, putting articles in the paper, attending more meetings, holding more meetings.
We tried to continue in a more rational way.

We really, the Midwestern liberalism, believing in the democratic process, we thought our whole strategy from day one was to inform more people of our perspective, talk to them, give them a chance to think about this,
and eventually they'd influence a political process.
We really didn't go in for anything quite that sudden and radical because we thought that in this area it would only have a deleterious effect.
How about in the
Republican convention in Miami in 72, you've got the three Vietnam vets against the war who managed to shout down and interrupt Nixon's speech before they were dragged off.
Is that one of these radical gestures that you wouldn't have supported?
I wouldn't have supported that.
I would have, you know, if they wanted to interrupt him to make a point because they were not being presented a forum, that's fine.
But, you know, they thought it was necessary that they be dragged off.
We always tried to facilitate, you know, anyone and everyone's point of view, and we just didn't agree with some, and we would, you know, try to rationally discuss those.
